intro: Psilotrichum africanum, commonly known as the African clubmoss, is a member of the family Lycopodiaceae and is characterized by its primitive, spore-producing structure. It is a small, herbaceous plant that typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forests and rocky areas. The plant features a rootstock with upright, branching stems covered in small, scale-like leaves. Its reproductive structures include cone-like strobili that produce spores, typical of its ancient lineage. Psilotrichum africanum plays a role in soil stabilization and provides habitat for various microorganisms and invertebrates.
